topics: A first course in error-correcting codes.
Linear block codes, Hamming-Golay codes, and multiple error-correcting BCH codes are studied.
The mathematical ingredients for the course include linear algebra, groups, rings, ideals, and finite fields.
Demonstrate a fundamental understanding of the binary symmetric channel, decoding strategies, and the challenges with designing good codes;
Construct codes, and devise efficient encoding and decoding algorithms for them as a means of gaining exposure to the applications of linear algebra and abstract algebra;
Analyze the properties of major families of algebraic codes including linear codes, Hamming codes, Golay codes, cyclic codes, BCH codes, and Reed-Solomon codes.

Network simplex and primal-dual algorithms.
Applications to problems of transportation, distribution, job assignments, and critical-path planning.
The course covers mathematical models for optimization problems on networks.
The max-flow-min-cut theorem has many applications including its implication of the Menger theorem in graph theory.
Additionally, the course presents several algorithms for solving optimization problems on networks.
Linear programming and LP duality are central to the design and analysis of some of the algorithms.
- maximum flows and minimum cuts (max-flow/min-cut theorem, preflow-push algorithm);

topics: Notice of Recording
Computational Discrete Optimization Winter 2025

Formulations of combinatorial optimization problems, greedy algorithms, dynamic programming, branch-and-bound, cutting plane algorithms, decomposition techniques in integer programming, approximation algorithms.
A discrete optimization problem, broadly speaking, involves a discrete set of feasible solutions and a real-valued objective function that assigns a value to each solution.

Discrete optimization problems are of immense practical importance, are solved every day (sometimes each hour or more frequently) by many Fortune 500 companies;  well-known problems in the class include
This course provides an introduction to the broad field of discrete optimization and covers several classes of commonly used techniques for the design of algorithms, including:
Dynamic programming,
We will discuss algorithmic efficiency and introduce the basics of complexity theory.
For NP-hard problems, we will explore the field of approximation algorithms, which provides efficient methods for computing solutions with guaranteed quality.
Students will complete two practical projects as part of the course, where they will develop, implement, and test algorithms for specific discrete optimization problems.

topics: Introduction to Game Theory Fall 2024
A broad introduction to game theory and its applications to the modeling of competition and cooperation in business, economics, and society.
Classical game theory studies the competitive and cooperative behaviour of rational and self‐interested individuals in strategic environments.
It speciﬁcally develops beautiful analytic tools to analyze and model situations in which a person’s welfare is a function not only of their own actions, but also those of others.
This course is meant to be a broad and mathematical introduction to game theory and its appications.

course_name: CO481 - Introduction to Quantum Information Processing (0.50)
major_name: Software Engineering (Bachelor of Software Engineering - Honours)
topics: Introduction to Quantum Information Processing Winter 2024

Basics of computational complexity; basics of quantum information; quantum phenomena; quantum circuits and universality; relationship between quantum and classical complexity classes; simple quantum algorithms; quantum Fourier transform; Shor factoring algorithm; Grover search algorithm; physical realization of quantum computation; error-correction and fault-tolerance; quantum key distribution.
This course aims to give a basic foundation in the field of quantum information processing (often just called "quantum computing").

QIP is a multidisciplinary subject and therefore this course will introduce fundamental concepts in theoretical computer science and physics that will enable students to pursue further study in various aspects of QIP.
Prerequisites: A solid background in basic linear algebra (e.g. a good performance in MATH 235 or MATH 114) is necessary.

course_name: CO485 - The Mathematics of Public-Key Cryptography (0.50)
major_name: Software Engineering (Bachelor of Software Engineering - Honours)
topics: The Mathematics of Public-Key Cryptography Fall 2024
An in-depth study of public-key cryptography.
Public-key encryption, digital signatures, key establishment, elliptic curve cryptography, post-quantum cryptography.

An in-depth study of public-key cryptography, including: number-theoretic problems - prime generation, integer factorization, discrete logarithms; public-key encryption; digital signatures; key establishment; elliptic curve cryptography; post-quantum cryptography; and security proofs.
An in-depth study of public-key cryptography and number-theoretic problems related to the efficient and secure use of public-key cryptographic schemes.
Algorithmic number theory: Primality testing, integer factorization problem, discrete logarithm problem, elliptic curve discrete logarithm problem.
Additional topics: Pairing-based cryptography, post-quantum cryptography.
An Introduction to Mathematical Cryptography (2nd ed.), Hoffstein, Pipher, and Silverman.

Fundamentals of autonomous mobile robotics, including both perception and planning for autonomous operation, sensor modelling, vehicle state estimation using Bayes Filters, Kalman Filters, and Particle Filters as well as onboard localization and mapping.
Topics in planning include vehicle motion modelling and control, as well as graph based and probabilistic motion planning of (Micro Electro Mechanical Systems) MEMS devices.
This course covers four fundamental topics of Autonomous Mobile Robotics; 1) modeling, 2) sensors and perception, 3) estimation (localization and mapping), 4) planning and navigation.
Modeling covers kinematic models of various types of wheeled mobile robots.
Sensors include various types and algorithms (for vision and range sensors).
Estimation includes Bayesian estimation theory and its application to localization (and/or mapping).
Topics in Planning include odometry motion models and graph-based and probabilistic motion planning as well as obstacle avoidance (reaction-based) methods.

This course approaches the design of tasks, tools, products, and systems from a user-centered design perspective.

Such knowledge, called ecoliteracy, will provide a critical basis for your engagement in the 21st century, the “century of the environment”—not least because so many of the environmental issues we face derive in part from a limited understanding of how we are embedded within and dependent upon ecological systems.

Field ecology necessarily harbours an ethical component both because of our natural affinity for life (or ‘biophilia’) and because questions of ecological ‘impact’ and 'quality’ are necessarily value-laden.

In summary, this course introduces the main concepts and principles of ecology; the cycling of elements; energetics and structural organization of major ecological systems; population dynamics; impact of natural resource management practices and urban and industrial development on the environment; incorporating environmental quality considerations into development activities.
The lab sessions include field trips to study natural and disturbed ecosystems, urban and applied ecology.
By the end of this course, you should be on a path to life-long learning as an ecologically-literate citizen.

major_name: Software Engineering (Bachelor of Software Engineering - Honours)
topics: Ecological Economics Winter 2025
The links between economics, systems and the natural environment will be explored and future directions examined.
View requirements for ENVS 220
This course provides an engaging introduction to ecological economics, framed through the lens of Doughnut Economics by Kate Raworth.

Together, we will explore how ecological economics challenges the assumptions of conventional economics and expands its scope to address the pressing challenges of sustainability, equity, and planetary boundaries.
Using the Doughnut model as a central guide, we will examine the concept of a “safe and just space for humanity” and the interplay between social foundations and ecological ceilings.
Rethinking Growth: Investigating the limits of economic growth, the role of natural resources, and critiquing growth-centric paradigms.

Redefining Progress: We will compare conventional measures like GDP with alternative metrics such as ecological footprints, planetary boundaries, and well-being and indices of human to assess their relevance in shaping policy and decision-making.
Special attention will be given to the intersection of ecological economics with issues like climate justice, social equity, and intergenerational ethics.
Globalization and Local Action: Understanding the environmental implications of globalization and the role of local communities in driving sustainable change.
Understand and Differentiate: Explain the foundational principles of ecological economics and how they contrast with conventional economic theories and environmental/resource economics.
Articulate the core concepts of the Doughnut Economics framework, including social foundations and ecological ceilings.
Critique growth-centric economic models from ecological, social, and ethical perspectives.

Apply Analytical Tools: Analyze policy options like taxes, subsidies, quotas, and emissions trading through both economic and ecological lenses, considering their potential impacts on sustainability and equity.
Use systems-thinking approaches to apply Doughnut Economics principles to real-world challenges in areas such as energy, food systems, or urban planning.
Discuss the ethical dimensions of economic policies, including intergenerational equity and climate justice.

His research focuses on community engagement in ecological restoration and conservation projects.

Chelsea's course work encompasses: globalization and its influence on urbanization, modern urban planning techniques and practices, planning in defining urban landscapes, housing and community development, environmental law, sustainability in complex socio-ecological systems, built environment and health, and lastly, environmental problems and its influence on various communities.
Chelsea is currently furthering my studies in the social and ecological program as a MES candidate.
Up-to-date course information
Everything in this syllabus (especially guest speakers) is tentative and subject to change.
Exploration of the interconnected roles that communities at various scales
can play in a transition towards sustainability.
Examination of structures, options, initiatives, and decision-making processes involving a wide range of concerns, opportunities, and applications.
It is the knowledge that people have of each other, their concern for each other, their trust in each other, the freedom with which they come and go among themselves.”
ERS 253 explores communities and sustainability as a useful pairing of ideas and practices.

This will involve applying a broad and critically advanced approach to community and sustainability (plus a few closely related concepts, including complexity and engagement in governance and decision making, as key factors for attention); and aiming to identify the practical implications, including for particular undertakings that aim to contribute to lasting wellbeing at the community scale.
There are cultural, occupational, ideological and interest-based communities, among others.

The course work will include development and application of tools to build an integrated understanding of communities, sustainability and engagement and to expand this understanding in discussions about issues and actions in a variety of particular areas of concern and opportunity (food systems, growth, decline, economic greening, ecosystems, etc.).

Perhaps most importantly, each participant will integrate the broad insights, specify them for the particular context of a community of her or his choice, and apply the results in the conception and evaluation of a sustainability-enhancing undertaking in that community.
The latter half is focused on application – we will return to many of the concepts in our readings and apply them to real-world cases with exciting guest speakers.

We cover multiple perspectives in economics and trace the evolution of key drivers, debates, and policy approaches before turning to new frontiers of research and practice.

The course format combines interactive lectures with exercises to build skills in economic and policy analysis, technical writing (policy briefings) for specialized audiences, and data analysis and visualization.

major_name: Software Engineering (Bachelor of Software Engineering - Honours)
topics: Climate Change Fundamentals Winter 2025
Climate change is one of the most profound environmental and social issues affecting communities, nations and individuals.
Climate change is a pervasive and challenging phenomenon that can be viewed through a multitude of lenses.

A scientific lens, for instance, reveals altered ecosystems and climatic tipping points while the lens of ethics raises the question of the right to develop and influence the well-being of others while doing so.

By carefully laying the scientific foundations, we will explore creative, positive, nuanced visions of the future that are rooted in scientific understanding of earth systems but also capture (or at least begins a conversation about) core human values, such as equity, compassion, innovation, and connection.
Demonstrate understanding of key elements of the climate system, and how these elements are being altered by the human emission of greenhouse gases.
Carefully consider the impacts of climate change on both human and natural systems.
Articulate the difference between climate change adaptation and mitigation, and understand a portfolio of actions that communities can take to respond to climate change.
Understand the key issues at play in international climate change negotiations, as well as recent Canadian policy proposals.
Investigate futures that are fundamentally sustainable, low-carbon, and resilient to climate change impacts.
Week 2: Introduction to the climate system, discussion activity, quiz

course_name: PLAN451 - Environmental Planning in Rural and Regional Systems (0.50)
major_name: Software Engineering (Bachelor of Software Engineering - Honours)
topics: Environmental Planning in Rural and Regional Systems Fall 2024
Drop-in times: Tuesday 9:30am-10:30am
This course explores environmental planning in rural and regional systems.
Introduction
In this course we focus on rural and regional systems for a couple of reasons.

This course is intended to offer practical insight into the use of environmental planning to address complex social – ecological challenges currently facing human communities and how to navigate this complexity in the face of multiple often conflicting land uses and community values.

We will examine topics such as climate change, biodiversity conservation, ecological connectivity, water management, and natural resource development, in a larger regional context, recognizing that these environmental issues invariably will cross political and administrative planning boundaries and include multiple disciplines and managers.

The purpose of this course is (a) to examine the concept and application of environmental planning in rural and regional systems, (b) to explore methods and tools that can be used to address environmental problems and blend social, economic, and environmental community values, and (c) to garner an appreciation of practical challenges and possible opportunities to proactively integrate environmental issues into future development choices.
The course is focused on a social-ecological systems perspective.
Seminar topics are on specific social and ecological system issues, problems, and considerations.
This course seeks to introduce the students to issues that affect environmental planning in rural and regional systems and expand the knowledge base needed by an environmental planner.
Assess how planning can help address environmental problems in distinct rural contexts
Evaluate how planning tools can be adapted within rural and regional systems
Develop skills in approaches including participatory rural appraisal, collaborative planning, and stakeholder analysis

major_name: Statistics (Bachelor of Mathematics - Honours)
topics: Introduction to Differential Equations Winter 2025
Solving linear differential equations: first- and second-order scalar equations and first-order vector equations.
The main purpose of the course is to explore how first and second order differential equations (DEs) are used to model physical systems and predict their behaviour.
first order linear DE models of compartment problems, atomic decay, and bodies in motion;
first order separable DE models of population growth;
a first order exact DE model of the electric dipole;
second order linear DE models for oscillatory systems such as mass-spring-damper systems and electrical circuits;
second order nonlinear DE models for suspended cables and rocket motion;
linear vector DE models of multiple compartment problems and species interactions.
Both analytical solution techniques and qualitative methods (direction field analysis, dimensional analysis, and phase portraits) will be presented as ways to gain information about system behaviour.
We will investigate conditions for existence, uniqueness, and continuity of solutions of both first and second order initial value problems, and for systems in the plane.
Maple will be used to generate numerical and graphical solutions, to illustrate concepts graphically, and to explore model behaviour.
increase your comprehension of some of the many ways that differential equations can help us understand the real world;
develop your ability to understand a mathematical model for a specific situation;
explore analytical and qualitative solution methods for first and second order differential equations, and the use of Maple; and

Knowledge Base - Demonstrated competence in university level mathematics, natural sciences, engineering fundamentals, and specialized engineering knowledge appropriate to the program.
Problem Analysis - An ability to use appropriate knowledge and skills to identify, formulate, analyze, and solve complex engineering problems in order to reach substantiated conclusions.

Investigation - An ability to conduct investigations of complex problems by methods that include appropriate experiments, analysis and interpretation of data, and synthesis of information in order to reach valid conclusions.

Design - An ability to design solutions for complex, open-ended engineering problems and to design systems, components or processes that meet specified needs with appropriate attention to health and safety risks, applicable standards, and economic, environmental, cultural and societal considerations.
Communication Skills - An ability to communicate complex engineering concepts within the profession and with society at large.

Such ability includes reading, writing, speaking and listening, and the ability to comprehend and write effective reports and design documentation, and to give and effectively respond to clear instructions.
Professionalism - An understanding of the roles and responsibilities of the professional engineer in society, especially the primary role of protection of the public and the public interest.
Impact of Engineering - An ability to analyze social and environmental aspects of engineering activities.

Such ability includes an understanding of the interactions that engineering has with the economic, social, health, safety, legal, and cultural aspects of society, the uncertainties in the prediction of such interactions; and the concepts of sustainable design and development and environmental stewardship.

Lifelong Learning - An ability to identify and to address their own educational needs in a changing world in ways sufficient to maintain their competence and to allow them to contribute to the advancement of knowledge.

Introduction to the basic theory and principles of mechanics of static systems.
Applications of mechanical principles to musculoskeletal systems will be presented.
Basic concepts of mechanics, vectors.
Analysis of trusses and frames.

Engineering mechanics involves the combination of physics and mathematics to develop models of physical world and solve problems in the physical world.
In this course, you will acquire knowledge of the theory and principles of engineering mechanics of static systems and become proficient in problem solving in this area.

You will acquire skills in analysing a problem, developing a plan to solve the problem including creating a mechanics-based model of the system, and proceeding to solve the problem with full understanding of the fundamentals and approach, not by memorization.
Examples of the application of statics to mechanics of materials and musculoskeletal biomechanics will be discussed.

Design of human-machine environments, design to reduce human error.
Analytical methods of determining user needs in systems with humans.
Information processing and human sensory processes and consideration of these elements in the design of systems with humans.
Human physical capabilities and consideration of these in ergonomic design.
Prereq: 1B Systems Design Engineering.
SYDE 162, Human Factors in Design, is the second course in the SYDE Design course sequence.
We will extend learning from SYDE 161 Introduction to Design by focusing on user/workplace requirements as they apply to the design of human-machine systems.

In Human Factors in Design, we will introduce students to the discipline of human factors engineering and how it informs design decisions to improve design outcomes from the perspective of overall safety and human performance.

Students will be exposed to human factors engineering concepts and analytical techniques relating to user experience and usability design, physical workplace design, and complex system design through lectures, assignments, case studies, and tests.
Outline and illustrate a basic understanding of human physical and psychological capabilities and how these affect a person's ability to work and interact with technology.
Appreciate the ethical responsibilities when conducting Human Factors/User Research (GAs 8a and 10a,b,c)
Apply risk analysis techniques to develop a complete and holistic understanding of incidents involving human error.
Apply human factors engineering concepts to analyze case studies and real-world design problems.
Investigate stakeholder requirements in the context of user, task, and environmental characteristics.
Critique and recommend redesign solutions for case studies and real-world problems based on human factors analytical methods.

major_name: Systems Design Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Data Structures and Algorithms Spring 2024
Email: shi.cao@uwaterloo.ca
Seyed Mohammad Amin Mirjalili <smamirja@uwaterloo.ca>, Online MS Teams communication and Q&A.

Algorithms and Data Structures emphasizes the following topics: structured software design, data structures, abstract data types, recursive algorithms, algorithm analysis and design, sorting and searching, hashing, problem-solving strategies and NP-completeness.
Prereq: Level at least 1B Systems Design Engineering or Computer Engineering Option.

This course covers the fundamentals of computer programming concepts and methods, including the following topics: data structures, abstract data types, recursive algorithms, algorithm analysis and design, sorting, searching, hashing, and problem-solving strategies.
These concepts and methods are used ubiquitously in software programming.
Knowledge and skills learned in this course will allow students to develop basic computer programs and build the foundation for learning more advanced programming courses.
As computer programming is involved in almost all engineering projects and scientific research, data structures and algorithms are becoming essential and even mandatory for engineers and researchers.
The course also increases students' interest in programming and prepares them for their co-op and future career.
Students will learn to analyze, implement, and use various data structures and data-management techniques in a variety of applications.
This includes:
Performing rigorous complexity analyses of simple algorithms and data structures (2c)
Comparing different data-structuring techniques from the point of view of time and memory requirements (4c)
Determining a suitable data structure to solve a specific algorithmic problem (4b)
Implementing data structures correctly and efficiently in a high-level programming language, such as C/C++ (4b, 5c).
2c: Critically evaluate solutions of engineering problems
4b: Generate and refine potential solutions to complex, open-ended design problems
4c: Critically evaluate and compare design choices
Topics and Deliverable
Introduction and Review of Programming Fundamentals
Pointers and Dynamic Memory Allocation
Algorithmic Analysis
Stacks and Queues
Sorting
Platform and Software Usage
Learn Slides and other learning materials
Students should use original variable names and comment their code thoroughly with explanation to demonstrate originality.
Students should save copies of their work on their computers and online file systems as backup in case of any problem.
Closed-book exams are used to test students’ understanding of the basic knowledge learned in this course and the abilities/skills to apply the knowledge to problem solving and engineering analysis.
